I'm often asked -- and occasionally in an
accusatory way -- "Are you atheist?" And it's

like, you know, the only "ist" I am is a scientist,
all right? I don't associate with movements.

I'm not an "ism." I just - I think for myself.
The moment when someone attaches to a philosophy

or a movement, then they assign all the baggage
and all the rest of the philosophy that goes

with it to you, and when you want to have
a conversation they will assert that they

already know everything important there is
to know about you because of that association.

And that's not the way to have a conversation.
I'm sorry. It's not. I'd rather we explore

each other's ideas in real time rather than
assign a label to it and assert, you know,
what's going to happen in advance.

So what people are really after is, what is
my stance on religion or spirituality or God?

And I would say, if I find a word that came
closest it would be agnostic. Agnostic -- the

word dates from the 19th century -- Huxley
-- to refer to someone who doesn't know but

hasn't yet really seen evidence for it but
is prepared to embrace the evidence if it's

there but if it's not won't be forced to have
to think something that is not otherwise supported.

There are many atheists who say, "Well, all
agnostics are atheists." Okay. I'm constantly

claimed by atheists. I find this intriguing.
In fact, on my Wiki page -- I didn't create

the Wiki page, others did, and I'm flattered
that people cared enough about my life to

assemble it -- and it said, "Neil deGrasse
is an atheist." I said, "Well that's not really

true." I said, "Neil deGrasse is an agnostic."
I went back a week later. It said, "Neil deGrasse

is an atheist." -- again within a week -- and
I said, "What's up with that?" and I said,

"I have to word it a little differently."
So I said, okay, "Neil deGrasse, widely claimed
by atheists, is actually an agnostic."

And some will say, well, that's -- "You're
not being fair to the fact that they're actually

the same thing." No, they're not the same
thing, and I'll tell you why. Atheists I know

who proudly wear the badge are active atheists.
They're like in your face atheist and they

want to change policies and they're having
debates. I don't have the time, the interest,

the energy to do any of that. I'm a scientist.
I'm an educator. My goal is to get people

thinking straight in the first place, just
get you to be curious about the natural world.

That's what I'm about. I'm not about any of
the rest of this.

And it's odd that the word atheist even exists.
I don't play golf. Is there a word for non-golf

players? Do non-golf players gather and strategize?
Do non-skiers have a word and come together

and talk about the fact that they don't ski?
I don't—I can't do that. I can't gather

around and talk about how much everybody in
the room doesn't believe in God. I just don't—I

don't have the energy for that, and so I . . . Agnostic
separates me from the conduct of atheists

whether or not there is strong overlap between
the two categories, and at the end of the
day I'd rather not be any category at all.

not most) Atheists, do not answer the question "Does God exist?" with the

claim such a thing, but from what I have observed they are a vocal 
minority.

Are you religious?

-No (Irreligion).

Do you believe in the existence of God or gods?

-No (Atheism).

Does God exist?

-I don't know (Agnosticism). 

I respect people's decision to label themselves "agnostic" or "an 
agnostic", but I always insist that they answer the question being asked of 
them. If someone asks them whether or not they hold a belief in a god or 
gods, then "Agnostic" alone is not a proper answer. In that case, they are 
either an Atheist or a Theist (including Deists) and there are no other 
answers. It is a true dichotomy, with "A-Theist" literally translating to 
"Not-Theist".

+Oscar Davila You seem like a nice fellow, so i'm going to try to answer 
politely. Understand, we see this stuff repeated every other day and it 
becomes very tiresome, but there's always hope these conversations can 
result in better understanding.

*"People need to understand that there's a huge difference between Atheist 
and Agnostic. Atheists and Agnostics are not the same whether you want to 
believe it or not."*

Almost everyone here understands that, almost no one here claims they are 
the same. You could have gleaned that by reading even a modest subsection 
of the comments.

*"Atheists are constantly attacking and, mocking and making fun of 
Christians, Agnostics don't do that."*

This is a generalization based on your experiences with a small minority of 
internet atheist activists. Making generalizations based on limited 
experiences is lazy, and a lot of other uncomplimentary words I won't 
mention. In other words, don't do it. Agnosticism has nothing to do with 
politeness, tolerance or being non-confrontational any more than atheism 
has to do with the opposite of those things.

*"atheists are constantly trying to convince everyone that there is no God, 
and they are constantly trying to recruit people"*

You're implying this is a trait common among all or most atheists, and this 
is *empirically* incorrect. Like most people who fire off this claim, you 
offer no proof.

*"there are many channels here on TY that do that, there are many books, 
and there are even websites"*

Atheism is a position on belief. It's human nature for those with a 
position to attempt to argue that position if they feel it's important. A 
small percentage create videos or blogs on the topic, an even smaller 
percentage writes books and gives talks. 
There are agnostics who actively promote philosophical skepticism, and 
withholding belief until you have sufficient cause or evidence. They're no 
different... they think the world would be better if people thought like 
they do. (as it happens, they're right... and most atheists agree)

*"So if that's not a religious, I don't know what that is then."*

Religions. Religions are a religion. It's really that simple. Calling other 
things "a religion" is just poetic license, and generally meant as an 
insult. Apparently you don't have a high opinion of religion, but you hide 
it behind a pacifist facade. 

A religion is an organized set of fundamental beliefs about the nature, 
cause, purpose and operation of the universe, usually involving rules of 
conduct or moral imperatives, usually revolving around a supernatural 
entity. Atheists don't necessarily agree on *anything* except that they 
don't see any reason to believe in "God".


To sum up on your primary assertion: we understand Atheism and Agnosticism 
are not the same. No one with any credibility is saying otherwise. The 
argument is over the assertion that atheism and agnosticism are *mutually 
exclusive*. It has been argued extensively, and in my opinion 
overwhelmingly successfully, that this is not the case. You are not either 
male or dark-haired. They describe different aspects of who you are.


Re: science...

*"For example I believe in evolution but that still doesn't prove that 
there is no God."*

Who is claiming that it does?

*"The big bang if you analyze it deeply you get to the conclusion that 
something has to have existed before"*

Not really. If the big bang is the start of time, then the concept of 
"before" is incoherent. You can make the argument that the universe has 
technically always been in a state of expansion, because there was never a 
*time* when time was flowing but the universe wasn't in motion.

*" I mean nothing can just appear out of nothing."*

Who is making this argument (barring equivocation on the term "nothing)? I 
feel like I'm asking that a lot.


There's a much deeper conversation going on here than the one you envision, 
Oscar... it's been going on for quite a while and it's gotten very deep and 
permeated many aspects of science, philosophy and epistemology. It can't be 
simplified and summed up in a few obvious admonitions, and it absolutely 
should not be dismissed with erroneous and insulting stereotypes.

Agnostic is an adjective. It modifies a noun. That noun should be a 
specific idea, not a person because "agnostic", by the very meaning of the 
word, is a "lack of knowledge". If you're calling yourself agnostic, it 
simply means you are a person who lacks knowledge (or claims none) with no 
context whatsoever (although religious context is generally implied). The 
reason atheists claim agnostics is because most self-proclaimed agnostics 
do not believe in a deity (although it's entirely possible to be an 
agnostic theist). Atheism, by its own definition, is the lack of belief in 
a deity. Whether you entertain the possibility or not is irrelevant, any 
agnostic who doesn't believe in a god is technically an atheist, just like 
any bisexual is also technically homosexual. A lot of agnostics like to 
think that they walk some imaginary middle ground, but the simple fact is, 
they are agnostic atheists, just like vast majority of other atheists. They 
simply don't want to be associated with that group because the in-your-face 
atheists (i.e. gnostic atheists) are just as bad as religious nuts these 
days.

As for why the word "atheist" exists in the first place, it's simply a 
matter of it having been a minority in the past. In older times, belief in 
a deity was more common or even mandatory, but as we grew more 
knowledgeable and capable of explaining events without having to rely on 
blind faith, the amount of people who choose not to believe in a deity is 
steadily starting to grow. If the vast majority of people in the world 
collected stamps at one point, you can be damn sure there would be a word 
for people who chose not to do so, even if the group wasn't that small 
anymore.﻿

+Gary Bell It all depends on which type of knowledge we're talking about. 
If we're talking about absolute knowledge, the problem is that there isn't 
really any way of proving *anything* with absolute certainty. *Absolute* 
knowledge is indeed unattainable. All that tells me however is that 
absolute knowledge isn't a relevant topic to discuss unless we're 
discussing philosophy.

Instead, agnosticism is much more relevant when speaking in terms of 
non-absolute knowledge. (the type of knowledge science deals with) 
Non-absolute knowledge can know things, but only with a degree of certainty 
based on the strength of the evidence provided. I can know that evolution 
is true, because the evidence is overwhelming, but I can't know that a god 
does not exist because *"absence of evidence is not evidence of absence"*.

Sure, some particular definitions of god that contradict themselves, or 
make claims that are testable ("Thor literally hurls lightning bolts") can 
be proven to be false, but that's not what I'm talking about.

A claim that is not based in evidence has no merit and can be considered to 
be irrelevant, but that doesn't give me justification to claim that I know 
the answer, because that is something I do not know, and in many cases, 
*cannot* know by definition.

If a person tries to claim that something is false based on a lack of 
evidence, they are committing a logical fallacy called "Argument from 
ignorance". (e.g. *"You haven't provided evidence, so therefore your god 
must be false"* is not a rational argument)

*"The gods that have been defined are easily falsifiable"*
I am very aware, and I want to point out that logical contradictions are 
evidence of non-existence. Knowing that impossible gods don't exist is 
consistent with the idea *"absence of evidence is not evidence of absence"*, 
because we have proof.

*"Being an agnostic is useless in regards to any intellectual debate about 
Zeus, Poseidon [...]"*
If there is evidence, we can know that something is false. We can prove 
that Thor doesn't ride across the sky in a chariot and throw lightning at 
people in the literal sense. On the other hand, if we say that Thor somehow 
interacts with the clouds in some unnoticable way to increase the chances 
of lightning when he feels like it, that's not really something we can 
know. We don't have any reason to believe that it's the case, but we don't 
know.

*"Not only that agnosticism is a claim of knowledge, a claim that says that 
no one past, present and future can learn knowledge, what a stupid thing to 
say."*
If it's possible to prove that a claim is unknowable, we can be cartain 
that no knowledge can be learned about it. *However*, a true agnostic must 
acknowledge that in many cases, we might not be able to know whether a 
claim is unknowable. In relation to things that we don't know are 
unknowable, like a lot of definitions of gods for example, we can only say 
that the claims are *currently* unknown. If we sometime in the future end 
up finding evidence either way, that is a different thing. 

*"You positively announce that science can't discover anything in the 
future?"*
I do not, unless the claim can be proven to be unknowable, such as the 
existence of something that does not interact with the universe in any way 
at all. (which also never has and never will)

*"It is also in reference to one god singular because Huxley used it only 
in reference to the Jewish god Yahweh, if you look at the definition it 
still only refers to one god, the philosophical exercise in linguistics."*
Agnosticism is a concept that can be applied to any claim, although it most 
commonly refers to the existence of gods.
